review.title: New Results on Equilibria in Strategic Candidacy
review.abstract: We consider a voting setting where candidates have preferences about the outcome of the election and are free to join or leave the election. The corresponding candidacy game, where candidates choose strategically to participate or not, has been studied in very few papers, mainly by Dutta et al., who showed that no non-dictatorial voting procedure satisfying unanimity is candidacy-strategyproof, or equivalently, is such that the joint action where all candidates enter the election is always a pure strategy Nash equilibrium. They also showed that for voting trees, there are candidacy games with no pure strategy equilibria. However, no results were known about other voting rules. Here we prove several such results. Some are positive (a pure strategy Nash equilibrium is guaranteed for Copeland and the uncovered set, whichever the number of candidates, and for all Condorcet-consistent rules, for 4 candidates). Some are negative, namely for plurality and maximin. We also study the existence of strong equilibria and relate it to a stronger variant of candidate control.

sections.heading: 2 Model and preliminaries

sections.heading: 2.1 Voting rules
sections.text: For the sake of completeness, we first define the general voting rules that we are studying in this paper. There are a number of n voters who vote from a number of m candidates. A single vote is a strict sequence of candidates. A voting rule takes all votes as input and leads to a result - a candidate who is declared the winner of the election. Although voting rules are usually defined for a fixed number of candidates, here, of course, we extend the definition to any number of candidates. All voting rules that we consider in this work are deterministic: we first define their non-deterministic version and assume that balances are distributed according to a fixed priority relationship with candidates. Since voting rules apply to different groups of candidates, we assume that equality rules are defined for the entire group of potential candidates and projected onto smaller groups of candidates; in other words, if x takes precedence over y, this will always be the case that c for each group of candidates contains x.

sections.text: The first question that comes to mind is whether the absence of a NE transfer to larger groups of candidates is not accompanied by a NE transfer.

sections.heading: 5 Strong Equilibria and Consenting Control
sections.text: Now we briefly discuss the link to control by deleting or adding candidates that are so unique. Bartholdi et al. [2] define constructive control by deleting candidates (CCDC) and constructive control by adding candidates (CCAC): an instance of the CCDC consists of a profile P about candidates removing candidates C, a holistic candidate K, and we ask if there is a subset C in which there is a subset C, so that the clear winner is in C. An instance of the CCAC consists of a profile P about candidates, candidates C1, C2, a differentiating candidate C, and we ask if there is a subset C of C2, so that the clear winner in C1 is "C." Destructive versions of control are defined by Hemaspaandra [10]: destructive control by deletion (DCDC) is similar to the CCDC, except that we ask if there is a subset C.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: We have further explored the landscape of strategic candidacy in elections, achieving several positive results (for Condorcet-consistent rules with 4 candidates; for two versions of Copeland and for unfunded groups with any number of candidates) and several negative results (for plurality and maximin); we have also established a strong link to a new variant of candidate control that we believe has its own interest. Many outstanding problems remain, especially Borda with more than 4 candidates. Another topic for further research is the study of the totality of states that can be achieved by some (e.g. the best response) dynamics starting from the group or all potential candidates. In some cases, even if the existence of NE is guaranteed (e.g. for Copeland), we may already find examples that none is attainable by a sequence of the best answers. But other types of dynamics can be studied.
